I study how to use technologies to change and predict human behavior and health using behavioral psychology and artificial intelligence;
University of California Institute for Prediction Technology (UCIPT)

I was funded and appointed by UC President Janet Napolitano, to create the University of California Institute for Prediction Technology (UCIPT). UCIPT is the first and only academic institution studying how social data can predict and address important real world events like outbreaks of disease, crime, online/cyber safety, and national security.

Every day, there are billions of data points from social data like social media, wearable devices, and online search data. These data carry psychological information that can be used to predict people's behaviors and global events. We have brought together the world's leading experts across big data engineering, computer science and machine learning, and psychology. We are building technologies to predict and solve the world's most important problems, before they occur.

The UCLA Center for Digital Behavior is a highly interdisciplinary collaborative formed to advance research on the use of digital and mobile technologies to understand, predict, and change human behavior. Digital behavior research leverages the increasingly widespread adoption of new technologies, such as social media, wearable sensors, mobile applications, and “big data” from these technologies, to study human behavior.

It started as a psychology experiment. I got my insurance license to figure out why people don't buy health and life insurance to reduce their risk for major life events. I wanted to learn what it's like to be an insurance agent who talks to people about risk.
I learned that a lot of insurance products are a waste of money. People shouldn't get them.
